subject: µChicago: Trial and evolution
body:
µChicago, a monthly science newsletter. 
Problems viewing this email? 
View online.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
March 2025
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Trial and evolution
 
 
 
 
 
This summer marks the centennial of the Scopes Trial, a Tennessee court case that sparked public debate on evolution’s place in the classroom. Explore its UChicago ties in the 
Spring/25 issue of 
The University of Chicago Magazine
, and read on to discover the latest in evolution and ecology research.
 
 
 
 
 
These hips were made for walking
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
New reconstruction of the skeleton of 
Tiktaalik roseae
, a 375-million-year-old fossil fish. (Tom Stewart/Penn State)
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
A new 
skeletal reconstruction of 
Tiktaalik
, a 375-million-year-old fossil fish and one of the closest early relatives to limbed vertebrates, reveals that its ribs likely connected to its pelvis—a crucial step in the evolution of walking. Using microcomputed tomography scans, researchers modeled previously hidden bones and identified an area of connection, likely made up of ligaments, that could have allowed 
Tiktaalik
 to use its hind fins to push itself forward. Codiscovered in 2004 by Neil Shubin, the Robert R. Bensley Distinguished Service Professor of Organismal Biology and Anatomy, 
Tiktaalik
 remains key to understanding the evolutionary transition between aquatic and terrestrial life. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Natural selections
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
1
 
 
 
 
 
Armed and dangerous: New research found that octopus arms are controlled by a 
segmented nervous system
, allowing independent movement of each individual sucker and extremely fine motor control for grasping, exploring, and hunting. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
2
 
 
 
 
 
Hotter, drier, spongier: A fungus that curbs invasive spongy moth populations is 
predicted to decline
—leading to more and more tree damage—due to the hotter, drier conditions brought on by climate change, according to computer models of species interaction.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
3
 
 
 
 
 
Sink or swim: The 
debate over 
Spinosaurus
’s hunting style continues
 as new studies clash on whether the sail-backed dinosaur’s dense bones enabled it to dive deep for its food or if the species was too buoyant to fully submerge.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Spotlight
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Bless the rains
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
A new study suggests rainwater could have helped protocells develop their cell walls 3.8 billion years ago, a critical step in the evolutionary transition from RNA molecules to living organisms. (Illustration courtesy UChicago Pritzker School of Molecular Engineering/Peter Allen, Second Bay Studios)
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Researchers may have uncovered how 
early protocells first formed
 from simple RNA droplets billions of years ago. Scientists have long believed these droplets were the starting point for early cellular life, but the theory had a vexing problem: Under evolutionary conditions, the droplets exchange RNA so quickly that the process would have resulted in identical clones—not in the genetic mutations needed for evolutionary change. A new study from the University of Chicago and the University of Houston exposed these naturally occurring droplets to rainwater, which helped form a protective “barrier” around the molecules and slowed RNA exchange. This breakthrough addresses a major challenge in origin-of-life research by demonstrating how early protocells could have maintained genetic differences, fostering natural selection. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In case you missed it
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
At the heart of it:
 
American Heart Month observed—a look at the latest in cardiovascular research.
 
 
 
 
On the map:
 
Molecular “mapping” uses powerful next-generation microscopes to create diagrams of cells, genes, and even entire organs to better understand how they work within the body.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Support biological sciences at UChicago.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Sign up
 to receive 
µChicago
 monthly.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Biological Sciences Division
Pritzker School of Molecular Engineering
More science at UChicago News
More science at UChicago Magazine
 
 
 
 
 
The University of Chicago 
5801 South Ellis Avenue, Chicago, IL 60637 
1.800.955.0065

subject: NYS Tax Department: Withholding tax changes are live! Get ready to file.
body:
Having trouble viewing this email? 
View it as a webpage
.
Know what to expect for your filing due April 30
The improvements to our withholding tax and wage reporting Web applications, forms, and related content are now live. This means the filing process for your quarterly return—Form NYS-45, 
Quarterly Combined Withholding, Wage Reporting, and Unemployment Insurance Return—
due April 30, 2025, will be different.
To ensure you're prepared, review some of the key changes to the filing process, 
before 
your return is due. For a complete list of all the changes, visit 
March 2025 changes to withholding tax and wage reporting
. 
Key changes
✔ On Form NYS-45, you must:
file 
all parts together
,
include all employees for the period as a single filing, and
separately report New York State, New York City, and Yonkers taxes withheld for 
each
 employee.
✔ We discontinued our stand-alone Wage Reporting Upload application for Form NYS-45 within Online Services.
If you're filing for 
one employer,
 you may upload this information using 
NYS-45 Web File
. Note: If you are filing for multiple employer identification numbers (EINs), you must file for each EIN separately. You 
cannot
 use NYS-45 Upload.
If you're a payroll service provider filing for 
multiple employers
 and have successfully tested submissions with the Tax Department, you may use the new 
NYS-45 Upload
. 
✔ You can electronically file 
all
 withholding tax returns, including amended returns. The amended return must be a complete, new filing (including 
all
 return parts and 
all 
employee records, not just the changes). 
✔ We discontinued Forms NYS-45-X and NYS-45-ATT. If you are exempt from the e-file mandate, file and submit a new and complete 
Form NYS-45
 according to the instructions on the form and mail it to the address provided. 
✔ You cannot request a credit across tax years. If you have an overpayment on your fourth quarter return, we will automatically send you a refund.
Withholding guidance
If you previously used NYS-45 Web File or Wage Reporting Upload, you should now refer to our 
NYS-45 Web File instructions
 for upload file formats and guidance for wage reporting.
If you are a payroll service provider filing for multiple employers, refer to:
the updated 
Publication 66
, 
Electronic Reporting of NYS-1 Information
, when filing with 
NYS-1 Upload
; and
the new 
Publication 72.5
, 
Electronic Reporting of Form NYS-45 Information
, when filing with 
NYS-45 Upload
 (we have retired Publication 72, 
Electronic Reporting of Form NYS-45 Information
).
If you file through FSET or are a software developer, visit 
Approved vendors for Federal/State Employment Taxes (FSET)
 for guidance.
Withholding tax reminders
✔ If you're reading this on your device, you're probably required to e-file your withholding tax returns. To make it easier, watch our 
NYS-45 Web File demo
 and 
NYS-1 Web File demo
. For all your filing options, see 
Withholding tax filing methods
.
✔ If you must file a paper return, see 
Form NYS-45
 and 
Form NYS-1
 to access the current forms and their instructions. Do 
not 
use saved or printed copies of these forms dated prior to 2025.
Withholding tax resources
Visit 
Withholding tax home
 for all your withholding tax resources. To stay up to date, 
subscribe to 
Withholding tax 
emails
.

subject: Thoughts From the MindTaming Blog
body:
Musings and Meditations on Mindfulness
 
 
March 2025
Welcome to Issue No. 13 of MindTaming!
 
 
 
On My Mind:
 
Staying Calm in the Turmoil
 
“We don’t have the luxury of despair.” – U.S. Senator Jon Ossoff
Dear Friends,
This issue of “MindTaming” marks the beginning of year 4 of this blog focused on mindfulness practices, tools and resources. It seems that this type of practice is helpful to more and more people all around me. The mailing list for my Wednesday meditation group is growing every week. (For more information about this group and how to join, see the Community section below.)
Meditation and mindfulness practices are one way to keep ourselves centered and grounded amid the chaos, uncertainty and constant change all around us, no matter where we stand politically. There are many other ways. We just can’t give up – or in. 
Maintaining a positive inner state, growing our resiliency, staying calm, getting rest and relying on our resources are all things we must do right now. Why? So that we can be our best selves, offer calm and peace to others and take action that aligns with our values and circumstances. As a white, well-educated, middle-class female, I can do a lot of things IF I take care of myself and my loved ones.  
When so many things around me seem out of my control, it’s useful to focus on what I CAN control. My inner state and my physical well-being are things I do have control over. And they impact the way I show up in the world and the kind of behaviors I display.  
Here are a few things I have found helpful in these trying times:
Keep things simple and don’t aim for perfection
. 
Not meeting every single deadline is ok – just let people know you’re going to be late. 
 
Realize that things take time
. 
Don’t expect immediate results and settle in for the long haul.
 
Don’t give up hope
. 
“Hope is a discipline, a practice and a commitment,” says American educator and activist Mariame Kaba. Follow her advice.
 
Practice the 4 Cs
. 
Community, Compassion, Curiosity and Courage. 
 
Have fun and do joyful things
. 
“Joy is an act of resistance,” declares poet Toy Derricotte in her poem “The Telly Cycle.”
 
Finally, be gentle with yourself. Try things out and experiment. Reverse course if something is not working. Most of all, remember what really matters to you – and trust your inner voice. 
How are you going to bring joy into your life in the coming months? I am exploring the heel of the Italian peninsula (Puglia) on a bicycle in April before participating in the final AIDS Vaccine charity bike ride near Atlanta in May. I hope both activities will help me stay centered and strong for the challenges ahead of us.
Wishing you a beautiful spring,
Rita
 
 
Taming:
 
Cultivating Your Practice
 
Get physical. Do something new with your hands.
When I get nervous or worried or when I am looking for distraction, I find it helpful to do something with my hands. By using my body in this way and engaging a different part of my brain, I tend to feel more grounded and centered. There are many ways to “get physical” (in addition to exercising, cleaning, cooking, gardening, etc.).  For instance:
Knitting, crocheting, needlepoint or other kinds of crafts
. I recently found a great “crocheting starter kit” at an outfitters store. BTW, men knit, too. :-)
 
Working on art projects
. We did a lot of that during the pandemic. Why not resurrect some of the activities from a few years ago? I mentioned taking up water-color painting in my last blog (finally scheduled for May – some things take a while to come to fruition).
 
Doing
 
jigsaw puzzles
. 
This is a still one of my favorite activities during colder weather. I currently have a very challenging 1000-piece jigsaw puzzle set up in my living room on a nifty new 
“
puzzle board
”
 that rotates.
 
Another “physical” practice that many of us have lost touch with and that almost seems ancient and somewhat quaint now is 
letter-writing
. Yes, I mean a REAL letter, not a greeting card or a postcard (although those arrive at my house less and less frequently, too). I wrote about four or five letters this past year, and it was hard. My fingers were not used to holding a pen for so long, and my handwriting looked like that of a toddler towards the end of the letter. Still, I enjoyed this type of focused activity, and I felt good about the amount of physical and mental effort I had put into it once I was done. I also sometimes cut out newspaper articles and send them to friends – and they always comment on how touched they are to have received my letter. Why not surprise one of your loved ones with a special handwritten gift sometime?
 
 
Community: Offerings for Practicing in Community
Are you drawn to meditation? Have you tried it but gave up again? 
Join us online every Wednesday from 12-12:30pm EST for our free 30-min Midweek Mindfulness Meditation, and meditate with people from around the world. 
Drop in as you can. Includes a check-in, a brief talk and 10-15 minutes of silent meditation. Free and open to anyone who is interested in practicing meditation in community. If you’d like to receive a weekly reminder to participate, sign up 
here
. 
 
Cool Resource
s
Minimal Reliance and Hope
"10% Happier with Dan Harris” podcast": 
"
9 Ways to Break Free From the Habits That Are Holding You Back with Dr. Rangan Chatterjee
"
 
(2/3/2025). In this episode, Dan Harris talks with UK-based physician and author Dr. Rangan Chatterjee about things that can hold you back, including the tendency to only listen to what “the experts” tell you instead of practicing “minimal reliance” and trusting your inner wisdom. 
Substack seems to be THE place where podcasters and bloggers post their offerings these days. I follow several writers, authors, teachers and activists whose posts I find interesting and inspiring. Here is a 
post by author and activist Patti Digh on HOPE
 
(3/25/2025)
 
and how to strengthen your “hope muscle.”
 
Click here to read  previous posts
 
 
 
Want to bring mindfulness to your workplace?
If you or your organization are interested in bringing mindfulness to your workplace and would like to discuss what that might look like, please 
contact me
 - and we'll set up an initial (no-obligation) meeting.
 
 
Tell me what you think!
I welcome any comment or question about anything mentioned in this blog. Email me at
 
rwuebbeler@interglobeweb.net
. If you do not want to continue to receive this blog click the Unsubscribe link below and uncheck MindTaming. To 
subscribe 
please 
email

﻿

body:
Dear Randall Stieghorst,
You are invited to the following 
event
:
YS Think Intercultural Series: Unlocking Cultural Intelligence: A Practical Framework by Dr Catherine Peyrols Wu
When: 01 Apr 2025 12:00 PM, CEST
Where: Online
The event is in 5 days, have you registered?
Yes
 
Maybe
 
No
 
EVENT DETAILS:
Expand Your Intercultural Skills with this interactive session!
Part 1
 – Essential Insights (20 min)
What is Cultural Intelligence (CQ), and how can you apply its powerful framework to elevate your intercultural training? Discover key concepts and real-world applications.
Part 2
 – Engaging Discussion & Live Q&A (40 min)
Dive deeper into CQ with expert insights, practical examples, and an open discussion to address your biggest challenges in intercultural training.
Key Discussion Points:
✅ Start with the end in mind – What does true intercultural competence look like, and how do people actually develop it?
✅ Seeing clearly through the clutter – How to assess and choose the best intercultural frameworks for your training.
✅ Your training roadmap – A step-by-step guide to using Cultural Intelligence (CQ) to design effective, results-driven intercultural training programs.
Join us for this dynamic session and gain actionable strategies to enhance your intercultural training impact! ✨
Let’s connect, learn, and lead together!
Best regards,
Young Sietar

SG

 Randall Stieghorst <r.stieghorst@lcwmail.com>

 Tuesday, March 25, 2025 13:41

 Sarah Gluckstein <s.gluckstein@lcwmail.com>

Randy

body:

Ticket #24916695: Dropbox Support Chat

You can also reply by logging in to your customer portal at 
https://dropbox.com/support
.
Jameson, Mar 25, 2025, 6:44 AM PDT:
Hi Randall,
 
Thank you for chatting with Dropbox Support today! This email includes a ticket number for your reference.
 
To sum up our chat today, you mentioned that you were looking to refund the charge on 
randyst@gmail.com
 as it was renewed through the wrong credit card.
 
Thank you for confirming that you would like to proceed with refunding and downgrading your account. I have processed a refund for your purchase and your account has been downgraded.
 
Within a few business days, you'll see the amount of the transaction credited to the payment method used to purchase the subscription. You can see your account transaction history on your 
Billing
 page 
here
.
 
If you need anything else, please don't hesitate to reach out.
 
Regards,
Jameson
 
PS: Check out our library of quick videos that’ll teach you how to get the most out of your account:
https://help.dropbox.com/learn/video-tutorials
Randall Stieghorst, Mar 25, 2025, 6:15 AM PDT:
Chat transcript:
( 13:02:04 ) Visitor: Hello, my subscription renewed to the wrong credit card.
( 13:02:23 ) Jameson: Hello Randall, and thank you for contacting Dropbox support. My name is Jameson, and I will be more than happy to assist you with your issue, right away!
( 13:03:53 ) Jameson: From what I gather you renewed your subscription on your Dropbox account 
r.stieghorst@lcwmail.com
 using a wrong credit card.
( 13:04:12 ) Visitor: Sorry, it's for my personal dropbox (
randyst@gmail.com
)
( 13:04:23 ) Visitor: A "family" subscription
( 13:06:06 ) Jameson: No worries Jack, can you please provide me with the transaction ID for that charge? As currently I cannot view that account for security reasons.
( 13:06:46 ) Visitor: K7VNQHSMVYWF
( 13:07:22 ) Jameson: Thank you Randall! I found it, it's 
randyst@gmail.com
( 13:07:36 ) Jameson: Would you like me to refund and cancel that subscription so that you renew with a new card ?
( 13:07:51 ) Jameson: Currently the payment cannot be transferred to another card.
( 13:08:02 ) Visitor: Yes -- i have updated the correct credit card in my account now (it ends in 8683)
( 13:08:18 ) Visitor: As long as we won't lose the subsccription/files/data -- sure.
( 13:08:58 ) Jameson: No worries, no files will be deleted, you may experience a syncing issue until you re-upgrade if you are using more than 2GB, but it should be fine, I will proceed with the refund then.
( 13:09:21 ) Visitor: great, thank you
( 13:10:16 ) Jameson: All done! I can confirm that the refund has been processed. Just to keep in mind, in general it takes 3 to 5 business days for a refund to be processed by payment vendors.
You can also access the receipt directly from this page: 
www.dropbox.com/payments
( 13:10:47 ) Visitor: ok, thank you.
( 13:10:53 ) Visitor: I will go in and re-subscribe
( 13:11:04 ) Jameson: Happy to help! Is there anything else I can help you with, via our chat?
( 13:11:26 ) Visitor: that's all, thank you!
( 13:11:44 ) Jameson: Thank you for chatting with me today! I'll send you a summary of what we discussed via email. Please feel free to reply to that email at any time if you have further questions. We would love to hear how satisfied you are with the assistance received today via the following one-click rating, after I close the chat. Enjoy the rest of your day!
Please don't share personally identifiable information in attachments. This message may contain attachments. To view them and other support offerings, sign in to 
dropbox.com/support
. Learn more about how we use and protect your data in our 
Privacy Policy
.
[WR5D24-G9MYP]

subject: NYS Tax Department: Withholding tax online services will be down beginning March 20, 2025
body:
Having trouble viewing this email? 
View it as a webpage
.
 
Withholding tax online services will be down beginning March 20, 2025
In preparation for the changes to withholding tax and wage reporting forms and Web applications, the following online services will be unavailable beginning Thursday, March 20 at 4:00 p.m. Eastern Time:
NYS-1 Web File
NYS-45 Web File
NYS-1 Upload
NYS-45 Upload
New York State Federal/State Employment Taxes (FSET) program
View and Cancel a Scheduled Withholding Tax Payment 
We anticipate these applications being available Monday, March 24; we will notify you by email to confirm they’re available.
If you have a Form NYS-1 due March 21, make sure to electronically file by 4:00 p.m. Eastern Time on March 20. Alternatively, you can choose to file by paper so long as your return is postmarked by March 21.

subject: The Future of WordPress & AI – Register for DE{CODE} 2025
body:
Don’t miss out on sessions from industry leaders and innovators who build on WordPress.
 
 
A Must-Attend Virtual Event for Everyone Who Builds on WordPress 
Date & Time: Tuesday, April 15 at 10:00am
Americas (CDT) | APAC (AEST) | EMEA (GMT) 
The web is changing fast—are you ready? Join thousands of WordPress
®
 professionals at DE{CODE} 2025, a half-day virtual conference designed to help you future-proof your skills, business, and strategies. 
Hear from 20+ industry experts, agencies, and WP Engine product leaders as they share clear, no-fluff insights on AI, performance, digital strategy, and more.
Secure Your Spot Today
Why attend DE{CODE} 2025? 
 
For Developers 
Exclusive insights on WordPress & AI from top industry leaders, breaking down how AI will reshape search and site development in the next 24 months.
 
For Agencies 
Strategies to win more business—how agencies are adapting to AI, shifting client needs, and emerging revenue models.
 
For Marketers & Brands 
Marketing and business strategy sessions covering AI-driven SEO, MarTech, and digital transformation.
Secure Your Spot Today 
Don’t miss your chance to be part of the conversation. 
Register now
 and get ready to build a better web.

subject: March 12 webinar on Global Trust with Maria Todosiychuk
body:
Register Now for Our March 12th Global Trust Webinar! ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Global Trust
Registration now for this March 12th Webinar!
 
 
 
 
March 12, 2025 @ 11:30AM ET
 
 
 
 
 
Data from international surveys sheds light on the following questions: What is trust and why does it matter? How profitable is trust? How much real trust is there in the world? How is trust created across cultures? Using a case study, this session is designed to provide practical insights and actionable takeaways that participants can apply in their personal and professional contexts. This Global Trust session will deliver ideas about one of the most fundamental cross-cultural challenges and about building real bridges. 
 
Daylight Savings Time begins in the U.S. on March 9 and in Europe on March 30, so please double-check your time zone to avoid confusion for our March 12 webinar.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
MEMBER REGISTRATION 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
NON-MEMBER REGISTRATION 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
PRESENTER:
 
Based in Russia, 
Maria Todosiychuk
 is an old friend and colleague of SIETAR USA. She is known for her educational games such as Diversity Space Meeting, Culture Shock, The Global Team, and Intercultural Minefield which are used by many interculturalists across Europe and the USA for intercultural training. Honed over 15 years of working with major Russian and international corporations, Maria has her own style and views on how to teach tricky and complicated intercultural topics. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Unsubscribe
 | Sent by SIETAR USA 
4880 Lower Roswell Rd, Suite 165 • Marietta , GA • 30068

body:
March 6, 2025
 
 
LANGUAGE & CULTURE WORLDWIDE
100 SAUNDERS RD STE 150
LAKE FOREST IL 60045-2526
 
 
 
 
 
 
Reference Number: 
24UCHG2082
V1005095140
154,500.00:10.00:CHI
 
Dear Accounts Receivable / Credit Manager:
 
University of Chicago
 is engaged in a review of its disbursement process.
  
We have hired Broniec Associates to assist us in this endeavor.
  
Accordingly, please send a current open item statement or accounts receivable aging of your account activity with 
University of Chicago
.
  
Provide commentary on account issues where appropriate.
 
Account activity should reflect the following types of transactions:
 
•
  
Open invoices/credit memos
•
  
Deposits & prepayments
•
  
Uncashed Refund Checks
•
  
Customer-owned inventory, equipment or other property
•
  
Unapplied cash/cash on account/overpayments
  
•
  
Rent or CAM adjustments
 
 
We have established a separate PO Box, fax number and email address for responses.
  
Please return the requested information using one of the methods listed below.
 
Please include the reference number listed above in your response.
 
Mail
:
AP Review Team
Fax:
(800) 915-7761
 
PO Box 1388
Email:
StatementRequest@Broniec.com
 
Norcross, GA
  
30091-9986
 
 
 
If you have any questions, please contact our office at 
(800) 557-7888
 for further clarification.
  
Your prompt response to our request will be noted and appreciated.
  
Thank you for your cooperation.
 
Sincerely,
 
 
 
Shannon Flanagan
Accounts Payable Supervisor
The University of Chicago

is needed:
_________________________________________

_________________________________________

Your A/R Account Number for Us

March 6, 2025
 
 
 
Dear Accounts Receivable Manager,
 
 
It is our normal policy to promptly review payments and related discrepancies as they occur. Due to the large volume of transactions processed, we conduct annual audits and account reconciliations.
 
Please consider this letter as authorization to release any statements, invoices, checks or credit memos that may assist Broniec Associates in this process.
 
If you have any questions regarding this authorization, please feel free to contact me directly at 
sflanagan@uchicago.edu.
 
Sincerely,
 
 
Shannon Flanagan

, March 2nd, 2025 at 11 am  CET
.
Whether you were able to attend or not, we would now like to invite you to review our notes  from the meeting. 
Please find enclosed the official document 
YS GA 2025 Document

If you have any questions regarding the contents of this GA, please do not hesitate to contact us. Additionally, if you feel inspired after reviewing the document and have some ideas of how you would like us to proceed, whether that be volunteering with research, education & training, or communication, writing for us, leading your own webinar, or assisting with the TOIT+2026 planning, please do get in touch!

subject: Reminder: Special webinar on IRAs
body:
Register to join us on Thursday, March 20. 
Problems viewing this email? 
View online.
 
 
An individual retirement account (IRA) isn’t just a smart way to save for the future—it can also be a powerful tool for giving back.
 
Did you know that your IRA can be used to make impactful gifts to the University of Chicago? The Office of Gift Planning actively partners with alumni and friends of the University to assist prospective donors and their advisers with their charitable goals and plans.
 
Join us for an interactive webinar to explore the essential aspects of planning an IRA gift, including the benefits, tax implications, best practices, and more. Ample time will be provided for your questions.
 
This event is free and open to all UChicago alumni and friends.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Register »
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Thursday, March 20, 2025
11 a.m.–noon (CDT)
 
Via Zoom
 
If you have questions or require special assistance, please contact the Office of Gift Planning at 
giftplan@uchicago.edu
 or 773.702.3130.
 
Disclaimer: The Office of Gift Planning provides general information that we hope will be helpful to you in your tax, estate, and charitable planning. It is not intended as legal advice and should not be relied upon as legal advice. Figures, calculations, and tax information are based on US federal tax laws, regulations, rulings, and rates applicable at the time such information was prepared. Individual state laws can affect the use and benefits of IRA charitable giving. For advice or assistance with your situation, you should consult an attorney or other professional adviser.
 
 
 
 
 
The University of Chicago
5801 South Ellis Avenue
Chicago, IL 60637
1.800.955.0065

 at any time.

subject: March 12 webinar on Global Trust with Maria Todosiychuk
body:
Register Now for Our March 12th Global Trust Webinar! ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Global Trust
Registration now for this March 12th Webinar!
 
 
 
 
March 12, 2025 @ 11:30AM ET
 
 
 
 
 
Data from international surveys sheds light on the following questions: What is trust and why does it matter? How profitable is trust? How much real trust is there in the world? How is trust created across cultures? Using a case study, this session is designed to provide practical insights and actionable takeaways that participants can apply in their personal and professional contexts. This Global Trust session will deliver ideas about one of the most fundamental cross-cultural challenges and about building real bridges. 
 
Daylight Savings Time begins in the U.S. on March 9 and in Europe on March 30, so please double-check your time zone to avoid confusion for our March 12 webinar.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
MEMBER REGISTRATION 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
NON-MEMBER REGISTRATION 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
PRESENTER:
 
Based in Russia, 
Maria Todosiychuk
 is an old friend and colleague of SIETAR USA. She is known for her educational games such as Diversity Space Meeting, Culture Shock, The Global Team, and Intercultural Minefield which are used by many interculturalists across Europe and the USA for intercultural training. Honed over 15 years of working with major Russian and international corporations, Maria has her own style and views on how to teach tricky and complicated intercultural topics. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Unsubscribe
 | Sent by SIETAR USA 
4880 Lower Roswell Rd, Suite 165 • Marietta , GA • 30068

subject: Event Announcement: YS Think Intercultural Series: Intercultural Relationships with Liliana Baeckert, 04 Mar 2025
body:
Dear Randall Stieghorst,
You are invited to the following 
event
:
YS Think Intercultural Series: Intercultural Relationships with Liliana Baeckert
When: 04 Mar 2025 7:00 PM, CET
Where: Online
The event is in 2 days, will you be attending?
Yes
 
Maybe
 
No
 
EVENT DETAILS:
Alternate Title: "
International Love
"
Liliana Baeckert, author of the book (in Portuguese) Amores Internacionais, will be talking about intercultural relationships and international love.
Different topics to be discussed
: 
Managing cultural differences within an international romantic relationship
Managing the difficulties in the new country, new culture
Cultural differences as cultural shocks
A glamorous loving relationship, but is this really the case? 
     → One of the couple is always the migrant, and what are the consequences of their migration? 
Who does this dynamic affect more,  women or men? 
Is there even a solution for this situation? 
Liliana Tinoco Bäckert is a journalist and holds a master's degree in Intercultural Communication from the University of Lugano, Switzerland. She is a member of the Network for the Study of Journalism of Migration and Refuge in Latin American Contexts (Remolinos), at the University of São Paulo. 
In Switzerland, where she has lived since 2005, she specialized in migration and in anti-racist practices. She currently works in an office for foreign integration.
In 2020, Liliana launched the journalistic book about the reality of Brazilian women who married people from other nationalities.
Best regards,
Young Sietar

 at any time.
